MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Matter. - Prison Educational Facilities.

Speaker.P: I welcome this opportunity to raise this matter on the Adjournment, and indeed I welcome the presence of the Minister of State for this debate. Senator Catherine McGuinness has indicated that she has a particular interest in the subject, and I propose to stop my own contribution in time to enable her to participate in the debate.

MainHeading.P: There are two major criticisms of the decision by the Minister last week to close even temporarily and in practice seriously curtail the educational facilities at Arbour Hill and Cork prisons. The first is the decision itself, which runs contrary to the fundamental principle that the penal system should as a primary objective ensure the provision of full rehabilitative services designed to meet the needs of individuals in the prisons. In other words, imprisonment should offer the individual the opportunity for rehabilitation and should respect the fundamental rights of the individual. The second major criticism is the manner in which the decision was taken. It was done arbitrarily, suddenly and without consultation. As a result, years of dedicated commitment by teachers and indeed months of effort and commitment by individual prisoners themselves were simply brought to a full stop. The inevitable effect has been to undermine the values involved and to denigrate and lower the respect for and the self-esteem of participants in the courses and indeed to undermine the work and the professionalism of the teachers involved.

I propose, in a few moments, to trace the sequence of events which took place last week to illustrate how arbitrary and unreasonable the decision was. Personally, I cannot believe that the Minister could have been adequately and fully advised, and I would implore him, and implore him through the Minister of State who is here this evening, to take immediate steps to minimise the damage which has undoubtedly been done and to restore as quickly and as fully as possible the educational facilities and the services in both prisons. The Minister is a teacher himself and does not need to be preached at or told about the values of education. It appears to be a decision taken without adequate thought, reflection, consultation and preparation, but it has been a decision which has already caused considerable damage and which must at this stage be remedied and ameliorated as rapidly as possible.

I would like to make it very clear that no one denies that there is a very serious problem of over-crowding in our prisons. This is a problem which has been worsening over the years and particularly over the months. It has been the subject of a good deal of public debate and it is not something that has sprung up overnight; it is not new. It has been an increasing and a serious problem that has been gradually coming upon us for a variety of reasons. You cannot solve it at the expense of an essential service for the rehabilitation of prisoners without being completely counter-productive. If we withdraw all educational facilities or reduce them to an unacceptable minimum, while cramming more and more young offenders into our jails, then we will reap a bitter harvest and we will reap it within a very short time. Therefore I want to use the time which this debate allows to trace briefly, first of all, the background to the provision of educational facilities in our prisons and then to turn to the sequence of events last week which I have described as being unacceptable in the manner in which the decision was taken as well as the substance of the decision.

Looking at the general background, I am going to concentrate on the two prisons, on Arbour Hill and on Cork. Arbour Hill, of course, is a long-term prison and in many ways perhaps is even more a place where we should be concerned about the capacity to offer educational services and rehabilitation. It was opened in 1975 and at the time it was designed to accommodate 101 prisoners. However, because of the pressure on prison accommodation that number has increased. I am informed that at the beginning of last week there were 130 prisoners in Arbour Hill and that it is anticipated that the figure could shortly rise to about 180. This has meant that there is necessarily further crowding in cells and some larger cells are being used to house three prisoners. This overcrowding inevitably increases tension and anger and confrontation within the prison.

It is generally recognised by prison governors and by prison officers that the provision of educational facilities makes a very valuable contribution in defusing tension, in providing an opportunity for rehabilitation, in providing an alternative source of interest and involvement by prisoners. Even at that level we are doing two things which are likely to build up the tension — withdrawing opportunities for educational facilities and increasing the numbers who are being crammed into the prison.

The background to the provision of education is one of great effort and commitment against a lot of difficulties. It has never been easy to provide teaching facilities in our prisons. It has never been a case where all the doors were open and it was easy to do. The vocational education committees have been involved with the organisation of the educational services in prisons since 1972. In Dublin, the VEC was involved first of all in St. Patrick's and then in Mountjoy, and when Arbour Hill was opened in 1975 these educational facilities were first provided there for approximately 60 prisoners by three teachers.

Initially, they were provided in a recreation hall, and the hall was divided into different sections used for pottery, art, English and physical education. In 1976 mathematics was included in the subjects provided, and indeed in that year five students took maths and six took English in the group certificate examinations. Since then students have taken examinations at leaving certificate level. During the mid-seventies securing educational facilities in Arbour Hill was not an easy task. It was a constant effort on the part of the prison authorities themselves and the teachers who were providing the service. In 1976 and 1977 the recreation hall was used and partitioned into four sections. In 1977, 1978 and 1979 there was a four-roomed prefab in the east yard. In 1979-1980 and 1982-83, for that period of four years, a facility known locally as “The Cage” was used. This is a four-roomed prefab placed in a barbed wire isolation cage and therefore, I suppose, aptly and accurately called “The Cage” by everybody involved.

During that period it was promised, and indeed that promise was fulfilled in April 1984, that a custom-built educational unit would be provided, because it was recognised by the Department of Education, by the prison officials, by the VEC and by the teachers involved with the prisoners themselves, that “The Cage” was not an adequate location for the provision of teaching facilities for a number of different reasons which I think do not have to be further spelt out. The education unit, therefore, was brought on stream just over a year ago. It is that unit which has now been suddenly arbitrarily and immediately closed last week by a decision of the Minister, and whatever temporary facilities may be provided in the meantime will be of an inadequate nature.

There was talk about going back to “The Cage” etc, but it is that unit which was for so long aspired to and waited for that has been suddenly removed from the teachers and the prisoners involved. The particular tragedy of it in a way, the heartache of it, was that the teachers themselves were very much involved with the planning of the unit. It is a very fine point, I gather. It is one that they are very proud of and it reflects their approach to the curriculum, as to how they see the provision of the educational facility and the facilities in it are such as we could be very proud of.

The facilities that were provided in this unit comprised the following units: four large rooms which were used for woodwork, pottery and art, drama and music and home economics, quite a wide and representative range of subjects. As well as that, in this unit were three general subject rooms, a staff room, two offices for private consultation for use with individual prisoners who were taking the courses and for career advice etc, and also — I think this is a practical aspect of it — two toilets, including a toilet for females because in fact a number of the teachers involved are female.

The number of teachers increased when the educational facilities were there. In 1975 there were only three teachers, as I said: in April 1985 the number had gone up to 15 teachers. There were eight wholetime teachers, including a guidance teacher, seven part-time teachers, of whom two were doing full-time hours, and I think this was an important aspect. It allowed a very exciting and full curriculum development on the basis of this custom-built unit in which the teachers themselves had a very large part. That is what, if you like, has been swept away by the decision. The increased capacity for the teaching and involvement of teachers is reflected in the involvement of the students, because up to the middle of last week, 70 per cent of the students were taking courses — five were taking group certificate examinations, five were taking leaving certificate, 12 were taking basic literacy courses and seven were taking open university courses. Now, all of that has been suddenly stopped. Last week they were doing courses leading to examinations: this week they are doing nothing. Yet these are vulnerable citizens who are deprived of their liberty by the State, who are imprisoned in our prisons and this is how we are dealing with them. That is the position in Arbour Hill.

The position in Cork is similar in this respect, that in Cork also there was a custom-built education unit and therefore a facility which had been thoughtfully provided in order to enable this education facility to be supplied. There were eight rooms involved and eight teachers. I understand that the teachers have not been deprived completely of access to this unit. They have been confined to three rooms. I understand there was a meeting of some representatives of the teachers and the Minister for Justice this afternoon and an issue arose about another section of Cork prison which at the moment is not being used but which had been intended for use as a workshop area. The teachers in Cork have raised the point that this area could have been taken over for necessary accommodation since it was not actually in use. The Minister seems to have been under the impression that the teachers had been offered that area. My information from the teachers and from their union is that this was not the case, that they had not been offered it, that they were given access to three rooms which would greatly reduce their teaching capacity and that there was a possibility of four other smaller rooms in a different section of the prison becoming available in a corridor. In any case, there was a very substantial reduction in the capacity.

Now how did this happen? I think it is worth looking at how these decisions were arrived at. As I understand it, the governor of Arbour Hill was informed at a meeting on Wednesday, 24 April, that it was intended to close the educational unit in Arbour Hill. He informed the teachers at 2 p.m. on the Thursday that this would happen and therefore they would not be teaching on the Friday. There was no consultation, no prior discussion, no warning, no lee time offered. They were presented with a fait accompli.

Speaker.P: Could I remind you that I have to call the Minister at 8.20 p.m., in five minutes time?

Very well. I will finish with a very brief synopsis of what happened because I think it is relevant. On Friday 26 April the teachers in Arbour Hill planned to hold a staff meeting there. They could not even do that because prisoners had been assigned to clear out the rooms. It was as sudden and brutal as that. Subsequently they contacted their union and on the advice of their union presented themselves at the resource centre office accommodation in Mountjoy. That is as far as they have been able to go at this stage.

MainHeading.P: Now the questions to which I hope the Minister will be able to give some answers are first, when is it intended to restore these two custom-built education units for education in the two prisons. Secondly, in the meantime while we are waiting for that to happen, what accommodation, what resources are going to be available? They are not even talking about the same prison accommodation. The additional prisoners who have been moved to these two prisons are entitled to access to educational facilities, and it is extremely important that the Minister in replying puts on the record of the House the fullest information to reassure and indeed to restore morale and to restore some of the confidence and indeed to match the dedication and professionalism of the teachers involved. I will stop at this point to enable Senator McGuinness also to contribute. It is hard, when one feels so strongly about something, to be brief, but I would hope that the Minister will take the opportunity to respond fully to the questions I have raised.

Speaker.P: I would like to thank Senator Robinson first for her courtesy in allowing me to add my words to hers on this matter because I feel particularly strongly about it. I do not want to repeat what she has said. I have very little time, but I would simply say that I had personal experience of going around all the prisons and places of detention in this country during the period of March to May 1982 in preparation of a report and study of them which has just recently been published under the title “Punishment and Imprisonment”. In particular, the group with which I was associated was extremely impressed by the efforts of the teachers in the prisons and the development of prison education. When we went to Arbour Hill we were shown precisely the developments that were going to take place, the building of this special educational unit and we were shown with pride by the governor of Arbour Hill and by the officials of the Department of Justice just what was being done in Arbour Hill and the hope that was being offered in particular to long term prisoners there.

MainHeading.P: Very important has been the way in which prison education has been specially developed to suit the needs of prisoners as opposed to the ordinary people who are going through the educational system. I think we must accept that a very large number of prisoners come into prison with a low level of educational attainment and many of them are virtually or completely illiterate. If we expect these people to go back into the community on release and try to live a normal life, go straight, try to get jobs and so on, the one thing that we must offer them to enable them to do that is education to qualify them for some sort of work. Here we have a position of people who are in a somewhat despair-creating atmosphere of serving a long term of imprisonment, who have made the effort and who are doing all they can to work for the group certificate and the leaving certificate and so on and suddenly, just before the season of the annual public examinations they are told that their education facilities are to be taken away at a moment's notice.

This is a totally wrong way of dealing with the present situation. I know that we all come under pressure from constituents and others — I just have about two more sentences, a Chathaoirleach — to deal with the present criminal situation by saying: “throw them all in jail and throw away the key”. I understand how people feel. I, too, have had my handbag snatched, my house burgled, my car stolen and so on. But that does not mean that this is the way to solve the problem. I would beg the Minister to give answers to the questions that Senator Robinson has asked and to restore the educational facilities in the prisons because we are not going to solve the problem of criminality and above all the problem of young criminals by taking away the one hope in the prison system, which is the provision of proper education.

It is a terrible blow to the system to find that these teachers who have put so much into the situation and who have developed prison education in a way that needed a great deal of initiative and devotion should be told at a moment's notice that their services in this area are no longer required and that the specially-made educational facilities that they had worked for for so long were to be shut down. I would ask that this decision should not only be explained but be reversed.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of Justice (Mrs. Fennell) Nuala Fennell
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of Justice (Mrs. Fennell)
Speaker.P: In replying to this debate I would like to say that the position in regard to the need to utilise the education units at Cork and Arbour Hill prisons as accommodation for prisoners was fully explained by the Minister during the course of his public statement of last Thursday. The need to increase prison accommodation is illustrated by the fact that on Thursday last the prison population stood at 1,799. Today it has increased to 1,832.

MainHeading.P: The decision to use the educational units to accommodate prisoners was not one taken lightly. The decision was taken after a full review by the Minister of the options open to him and in response to a situation which arose from circumstances over which he had no control. The units to which we are referring were opened only last year, teaching services having been provided until then in temporary accommodation. It certainly gave no joy to anyone involved in the administration of the prison system to have to take this decision. But the only alternative would have been to order the release of prisoners so as to make room for those being sentenced by the courts on a particular day.

In the course of his statement last Thursday the Minister indicated that efforts would be made to relocate teaching services in temporary accommodation. I am happy to be able to inform the House that consultations have taken place with the vocational education committees in Dublin and Cork aimed at identifying areas which can be adapted to enable teaching to go ahead. Earlier this afternoon, as Senator Robinson said, the Minister met representatives of the City of Dublin VEC and representatives of the Teachers' Union of Ireland. Certain proposals in relation to the provision of alternative accommodation were discussed with both parties. I understand that these proposals are to be discussed at a meeting tomorrow between the VEC and the teachers. Consequently, I do not propose to disclose the proposals at this stage.

Despite what has been said publicly by some people, it is not intended that teaching services should cease or even be reduced at either location or at any other prison facility for that matter. However, there is an important matter of priority here, and there must be a recognition that the primary concern of the prison system is to contain those sentenced by the courts. The education units will be returned as soon as suitable prison accommodation becomes available. It is not possible to give a date because it is not possible to foresee how these trends will develop. However, as soon as such accommodation becomes available the units will be returned to use as educational accommodation.

It is also a factor to note that the gardaí are meeting with success in their efforts to combat car thefts in particular, the rate of car thefts in Dublin having been reduced by 50 per cent over the last few months and crime generally having been reduced last year for the first time in very many years. On the points made about the use of alternative sanctions, community service orders which were introduced last December have been imposed in 104 cases. In addition social inquiry reports have been requested by the courts in a further 100 cases. There is little doubt that but for community services those 104 offenders would have been sentenced to imprisonment. Also, the financial resources available for hostels etc. have been increased by 133 per cent since this Government took office and expenditure this year will total £1.285 million.

As regards the comments made to the effect that the taking over of the education units represents evidence of a lack of commitment by this Government to education for prisoners, the facts are that there are now more teachers working in the prisons than when we took office. Educational services now available include third level courses, and teachers are now working in Limerick and Portlaois prisons, which had never previously been the case.

I can only conclude by saying that if the gardaí are to continue to have the success which they are currently having in dealing with criminals, additional space must be provided in the prisons and that it is inevitable that some reduction in services to prisoners will occur. Hopefully, those who have taken part in criminal activities up to now in the knowledge that they would only have to serve a small part of their sentences due to overcrowding will realise that this is no longer the case. The reduction in crime, in particular car thefts, is attributed in part at least by the gardaí to increased prison accommodation.

Speaker.P: May I ask the Minister one question arising from what the Minister said, that it was not intended that the teaching facilities would be reduced, but I thought at the end she did say that they would be reduced. If we could just know, for example, from now until the end of July, which would be the normal teaching period in Arbour Hill and Cork, will facilities be available so that the same number of teachers can teach approximately the same number of prisoners?
As I mentioned, the Minister has had meetings today with the VEC and TUI. I have no doubt but that there will be developments from that. I am not in a position to say what they are at present.
